title: The Assassination of Martin Luther King, Jr. Part I | STUFF YOU SHOULD KNOW

rawLines.text: welcome to Stuff You Should Know a
production of iHeart
Radio hey and welcome to the podcast i'm
Josh and there's Chuck and it's just the
two of us today which is fine uh because
we need to keep our nose to the
grindstone uh and really focus on a pair
of really important episodes which we
kick off now that's right uh we haven't
done a two-parter in a while but as we
got into the originally one-parter of
the assassination of Martin Luther King
Jr you were like "Man there's a lot more
here that we can just uh kind of explode
this into a a two-parter." Yeah that was
verbatim what I said and I said "Let's
do it." Uh there was a ton of stuff that
I did not know about MLK's assassination
yeah same james Earl Ray like there is a
lot of stuff around it and it's just a
reminder
that history gets so boiled down to like
its its bare essence or even like a
caricature of itself and when you really
dig into like a historical event it you
just you're just reminded that there's
just so many people affected and
involved and it's not just you know
James Earl Ray shot Martin Luther King
Jr and you know the world mourned i mean
right that was all true but there was
just so much more to it so hopefully
we'll kind of get some of that across in
this yeah for sure i mean you know we'll
talk about it some but I went to I've
been to the King Center i've been to the
Civil Rights Museum in Memphis at the
Lraine Motel and like I've thought I
knew a lot about this stuff but until we
do our job uh like we do I learned a lot
more so it's pretty great so let's talk
MLK um because he kind of skyrocketed to
prominence
um from just the start he uh became
involved in the Montgomery bus boycott
which most people say kicked off the
civil rights era in the United States
thanks to Rosa Parks um who we did an
episode on rosa Parks agent of change
you remember that one that's right that
was good oh yeah for sure uh and all
this is just you know so we're setting
the table kind of as a leadin to where
things were in April of 1968 yes uh so
like you said you know 12ish years
earlier is when he really rose to
prominence uh and and so much so that in
February of 57 uh he was on the cover of
Time magazine
uh so in 1963 uh he was Times man of the
year after being on the cover just you
know a handful of years earlier m and in
1964 he won the Nobel Peace Prize so he
was one of the most famous Americans by
the early 1960s yes um but one of the
things you don't learn about these days
as often is that he was at that point um
beginning to become widely criticized um
not just by white Americans many of whom
had been criticizing him all along but
by black Americans as well um there was
a real um division in the civil rights
movement between Martin Luther King's
vision of um his doctrine of nonviolence
which is basically saying like "Hey
we're we're going to um essentially do
everything we can to show white
Americans the the problems that black
Americans face just by being black in
America and um no matter what they do to
us we're not going to fight back and
we're going to make an example of
ourselves to that that we'll hopefully
set for them and the ultimate goal was
to integrate into America to integrate
black Americans into America so that
there wasn't black America and white
America and that ran very much contrary
to the other rival idea which was
Malcolm X's idea yeah and uh we haven't
um done one on Malcolm X yet so maybe we
should uh we should hit that up uh as a
follow-up at some point for sure um but
yes this was you know sort of the other
side of the coin malcolm X believed in
black separatism he was like "This
non-violent approach isn't isn't working
and and black people cannot integrate
into white America um it's a racist
society and it's just not possible so we
need um self-determination um violence
you know by any means necessary is an
acceptable sort of avenue to achieve the
goals of black determination um and
especially considering violence is being
uh inflicted upon uh black people by
white people constantly so it's time to
fight back like with fist and clubs and
whatever else yeah and and again that's
totally contrary to King's doctrine of
nonviolence which Malcolm X considered
criminal as he put it in the face of
just being beaten by whites just for for
marching in the streets peacefully and a
big portion of the people who are
critical of King and his non-violence
doctrine were the younger generations
they tended to lean more militantly more
in Malcolm X's direction um and then on
on in white America with white Americans
there he was basically never popular
during his lifetime at least with the
majority of white Americans yeah i mean
and we know this because you know they
did polls back then uh there were Gallup
polls that found uh in 1963 through 1966
each year found that fewer than 40% of
white Americans viewed uh Martin Luther
King Jr uh favorably so uh one of the
other things that didn't help besides
his work in the you know in civil rights
was uh his stance on Vietnam and the war
in Vietnam uh he was always against it
but um really changed his stance in 1967
started being really really vocal about
it as far as publicly condemning the war
uh started leading anti-war marches
giving speeches against the war um one
very famous one was uh Beyond Vietnam
colon a time to break the silence a
speech he gave in New York City at
Riverside Church in April actually
exactly one year April 4th 1967 before
his murder uh and it was a very
controversial speech because it was his
most adamant anti-war antivietnam speech
yet and he specifically called out uh
America and the and the US military by
sending a disproportionate number of um
you know kind of poor black American
boys to fight that war yeah and so this
was it's really hard to overstate how
controversial the speech was like he
just stopped mincing words and came out
and said everything that needed to be
said um and so his alliance with Lyndon
Bane Johnson who was president at the
time was just shattered right then lbj
stepped away from him publicly broke
with him i think um Laura helped us out
with this she found 168 newspapers uh
issued editorials denouncing him for
that speech so that like he was already
not super popular uh with white
Americans he his popularity was so so
with black Americans and all Americans
um were now mad at him for his stance on
Vietnam or a ton of them were and then
one of the other things that really um
proved to be very difficult for him
later in his life later in his career um
was he shifted focus from strictly civil
rights for black Americans to economic
justice for poor Americans of all races
um he uh he created something called the
poor people's campaign he came up with
an economic bill of rights that is
essentially pretty socialist i mean at
its core um and he also basically said
like this campaign is also going to be a
shift not just in focus but in um
potency like we're not going to be quite
as peaceful as we were before we're not
going to go Malcolm X like full-on
militant but we're you can expect you
know I think he famously said 15 to 16%
more militancy right yeah and you know
this ship so he already had you know
people coming at him from all sides and
now even within his own camp um they
didn't love it either his advisers and
his staff uh didn't love this change of
direction um so you know by the time
April of 1968 rolls around he's
exhausted he's tired he's um got people
coming at him from every angle even
within his own camp and he just wasn't
at at his peak personally or with his
career Right so Chuck do you want to uh
take a break now yeah uh we've set the
stage with where King was and we'll come
back and then set the stage with uh
Memphis and where Memphis was well it
was in Tennessee but how Memphis was in
April of 1968
[Music]
so in the spring of 1968 Memphis
Tennessee which had previously prided
itself on its um white community and
black communities kind of you know
fairly getting along especially compared
to some other places like uh places in
Alabama um it was by this time in high
tension as a town um and it was largely
because of the Memphis sanitation worker
strike mlk became very interested in in
helping further the goals of the Memphis
sanitation workers in their strike
because he basically saw this as like
this is a perfect bridge between this
transition from a focus just on civil
rights to this larger focus on poor
people of all colors
because like this was mostly almost
exclusively black sanitation workers who
were struggling for recognition of their
work dignity in their work um decent
wages apparently if you were a full-time
sanitation worker in Memphis you were
still eligible for food stamps after
your full salary um and he he was like
"This is this is this is exactly the
perfect kind of thing that I'm trying to
get across like this is important." So
he kind of focused on Memphis in the
spring of 1968 um and like I said it was
in in a state of high tension because a
couple of um protests marches
essentially to support the workers had
um not really gone really well
previously yeah but before these uh
marches there was you know there was
already a strike going on it just wasn't
you know full throttle at this point um
what would really kick that into gear
were the uh very tragic deaths of two
sanitation workers uh Echo Cole and
Robert Walker um they were crushed to
death their truck malfunctioned they
were trying to take shelter from the
rain and were crushed uh by the truck
and the city didn't didn't pay any
compensation to their families at all um
so this is what really kind of triggered
the the mass walk off the job um almost
all the workers uh black sanitation
workers went on strike at the time and
King was like "All right I I got to get
to Memphis it's in trouble uh it's an
opportunity for me as well like you said
to sort of um uh help me segue into into
this other movement um and there were a
couple of different marches on March
28th he led a march of 5,000 people um
through Memphis and almost right away it
it turned violent um not by his hand but
uh it was a group called the Invaders it
was a militant group of uh young
African-Americans who were not on board
with King uh they were not on board with
nonviolence obviously and they started
looting uh they started breaking windows
in stores police came in and you know we
we all know the drill at this point um
people scatter uh police are are beating
people shooting at people there was a
16-year-old named Larry Payne that was
shot and killed by a police officer
named Leslie Dean Jones uh 60 people
injured and then all of a sudden Memphis
is under curfew and close to 4,000
National Guardsmen are brought in yeah
and this was on the heels of another
march the the month before in February
where pro protesters including some
ministers who were marching were macaed
um by police so Memphis just like
basically almost like throwing a switch
went from like a generally okay city as
far as race relations were concerned to
like the National Guard is now here
keeping order in like a month it just
changed that quickly and because he was
leading the march on March 28th
um King became totally I don't want to
say obsessed but he was fully zeroed in
on returning to Memphis to set things
right because that was a huge black eye
in his against him his career and in
particular his whole um doctrine of
nonviolence and again like the invaders
were not related to what was going on
they essentially used this as a chance
to mix things up
um and King just basically wanted to go
give it another try and hopefully
restore his reputation hopefully restore
the reputation of the civil rights
movement he was leading and he put
everything on the line to go back to
Memphis uh and try it again because it
could have gone wrong again and that
would have really damaged things even
further a lot of his adviserss were like
"We don't need to go back to Memphis
like we have a a trip to Africa
scheduled and like let's just follow
through and we'll leave it behind us."
And he was like "No we have to go back."
So we actually canled that Africa trip
and um brought everyone back to Memphis
and he got back there on April 3rd and
that evening he gave um what's been
known uh today as his I've been to the
mountaintop speech i believe it was his
final speech gave it at the Mason Temple
Church in Memphis and uh it was a pretty
significant speech as you can imagine i
mean basically everyone's aware of this
but in it um he recounts an a previous
assassination attempt that I had never
heard of had you yeah from visiting the
museums but it's it's certainly not
something I don't think that's like
super widely known right well so he was
signing a book at a department store uh
when he was stabbed in a chest by a
mentally ill woman named Isola Curry uh
stabbed in the chest but with a 7-in
letter opener and Isola Curry was
convinced that civil rights
organizations like MLK's were tracking
her had singled her out were tracking
her preventing her from getting
employment just generally messing with
her life and um the papers all reported
that the surgeon who treated MLK
obviously he survived was that the
letter opener came so close to his heart
that had he sneezed it would have
penetrated his aorta and killed him so
he really locked out and he talked about
this in his um I've been to the
mountaintop speech but the thing that
most people remember about it is that he
he in a way almost predicted his death
the following day in the at the end of
the speech
yeah I mean I'll go ahead and read it he
he talked about not being around uh he
said "Like anybody I would like to live
a long life longevity has its place but
I'm not concerned about that now i just
want to do God's will and he's allowed
me to go up to the mountain and I've
looked over and I've seen the promised
land i may not get there with you but I
want you to know tonight that we as a
people will get to the promised land."
So uh a definite sort of eerie thing to
happen the night before his murder yeah
and I've read that some people are like
he was he felt like that death was close
that he didn't have much time left um so
it makes sense that he would have put
that in i don't think he expected to be
murdered the next day but he he just I I
read that he sensed that he he was not
going to live much longer yeah yeah I
mean he had seen what happened with

it was those kind of things you know
very sadly were were just much more

the time i just that's just nuts that

absolutely king Malcolm X the two
Kennedys uh yeah it's just
a very fraught fraught time in our
history for sure for sure so he's back

the march was actually planned for April

through the day and then late that

And King uh so late that afternoon the

forward but it's going to go forward

4th uh it was the evening it turns out
Bono got it wrong in that song Pride
because he says early you know they
corrected it did they yeah they they I

that was the room that he usually took

what boarding house bessie Brewer's

"That's where the shop came from." Um
the picture was taken by a South African

uh became one of the most famous you

Yeah i thought he probably died

so uh you know very famously Walter
